trial_identification.studytitle: Hypnosis Antenatal Training for Childbirth (HATCh): a Randomised Controlled Trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Hypnosis Antenatal Training for Childbirth (HATCh): a Randomised Controlled Trial

interventions.interventions:
Behaviour - antenatal hypnosis + audio compact disc on hypnosis Behaviour - Audio compact disc on hypnosis
No Intervention: Control - Usual care control
Experimental: Hypnosis + CD - Hypnosis plus audio cd on hypnosis
Active Comparator: Audio CD on Hypnosis - Audio CD on hypnosis sessions weekly on three occasions after 34 weeks gestation
Behaviour: antenatal hypnosis + audio compact disc on hypnosis
Behaviour: Audio compact disc on hypnosis

primaryOutcome.outcome: The use of pharmacological analgesia during labour and childbirth will be collected from the birth register where all analgesia is documented by the attending midwife

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 1. Maternal rating of the overall pain experienced during labour and childbirth
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Usually within 48 hours or before discharge from hospital

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 7. Maternal admission to the High Dependency Unit (HDU) or the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
8. Maternal rating whether the birth experience was. Worse / better / same as expected
9. Maternal rating of control during the labour during the birth
10. Maternal rating whether the birth was rated positive or negative experience
12. Length of maternal stay in hospital
13. Number of women breast feeding at discharge from hospital and at 6 weeks and 6 months

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - women > 34 < 39 weeks gestation; singleton, viable fetus, vertex presentation, who are not in active labour (active labour is defined as cervical effacement and dilatation associated with regular uterine contractions) and who are planning a vaginal birth.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Antenatal hypnosis is associated with a reduced need for pharmacological interventions during childbirth. This trial seeks to determine the efficacy or otherwise of antenatal group hypnosis preparation for childbirth in late pregnancy.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Cyna AM, Andrew MI, Robinson JS, Crowther CA, Baghurst P, Turnbull D, Wicks G, Whittle C. Hypnosis Antenatal Training for Childbirth (HATCh): a randomised controlled trial [NCT00282204]. BMC Pregnancy Childbirth. 2006 Mar 5;6:5.
